metadata.court_name: HIGH COURT OF DELHI AT NEW DELHI
key_issues: Infringement of trademarks by the defendants, specifically the use of the "VOLVO" mark, is a key legal issue in this case.
The plaintiffs' claim of passing off their goods as that of the defendants is another major legal issue.
The validity and enforceability of the global deed of assignment executed by plaintiff no.1 in favor of plaintiff no.2 are also at question.
The licensing agreement between the plaintiffs for the use of the "VOLVO" trademark is a relevant legal issue.
The plaintiffs' status as the registered proprietor of the "VOLVO" trademark and various "VOLVO" formative marks in different classes is a crucial aspect of the case.
The plaintiffs' claim that their "VOLVO" marks have acquired the status of "well-known trademarks" under the Trade Marks Act, 1999, is a significant legal issue.
The defendants' alleged unauthorized use of the "VOLVO" trademark, including the use of similar domain names, is another key legal issue.
The plaintiffs' entitlement to relief, including permanent injunction and other ancillary reliefs, is a major legal issue in this case.
The applicability of Section 2(1)(zg) of the Trade Marks Act, 1999, which defines "well-known trademarks", is also a relevant legal issue.
metadata.decision_summary:
**Case Summary: Aktiebolaget Volvo & Ors. v. Volvo White Paints Industries & Ors.**

**Background:**

The plaintiffs, Aktiebolaget Volvo, Volvo Trademark Holding AB, and Volvo Car Corporation, are Swedish companies that manufacture and sell vehicles, spare parts, and accessories under the trademark "VOLVO". The defendants, Volvo White Paints Industries, a partnership firm, and its partners, were found to be using the trade name "Volvo White Paints Industries" and operating the domain name "www.volvowhite.com" for their business of manufacturing and selling products like wall putty, tile adhesive, and gypsum plaster.

**Legal Issues:**

The plaintiffs filed a suit seeking relief of permanent injunction restraining the defendants from infringing their trademarks, passing off their goods as those of the plaintiffs, and other ancillary reliefs. The main legal issues in the case were:

1. Whether the defendants' use of the trade name "Volvo White Paints Industries" and the domain name "www.volvowhite.com" infringed the plaintiffs' registered and well-known trademark "VOLVO".
2. Whether the defendants' actions constituted passing off their goods as those of the plaintiffs.

**Arguments:**

The plaintiffs argued that their trademark "VOLVO" was a well-known mark, registered in various classes, including Classes 1, 2, 16, and 37, and that the defendants' use of the similar mark "Volvo White Paints Industries" was likely to cause confusion and dilute the distinctiveness of their mark. The plaintiffs also contended that the defendants' actions were a clear case of passing off, as they were trying to benefit from the reputation and goodwill of the plaintiffs' mark.

The defendants did not appear in court to argue their case.

**Court Findings:**

The court found that the plaintiffs had established a strong case of trademark infringement and passing off. The court observed that the plaintiffs' trademark "VOLVO" was a well-known mark, and the defendants' use of a similar mark was likely to cause confusion and deception among consumers. The court also noted that the defendants' actions were not bonafide, as they had no legitimate reason to use the mark "VOLVO" in their trade name and domain name.

**Decision:**

The court granted a permanent injunction restraining the defendants from using the trade name "Volvo White Paints Industries" and the domain name "www.volvowhite.com" or any other mark that was similar to the plaintiffs' trademark "VOLVO". The court also ordered the defendants to surrender all materials, including stationery, brochures, and website content, that bore the infringing mark. The court's decision was based on the principles of trademark law, including the protection of well-known marks and the prevention of passing off.

**Key Takeaways:**

1. The court recognized the plaintiffs' trademark "VOLVO" as a well-known mark, which entitled it to enhanced protection under the Trade Marks Act, 1999.
2. The court held that the defendants' use of a similar mark was likely to cause confusion and dilute the distinctiveness of the plaintiffs' mark, and therefore, constituted trademark infringement.
3. The court's decision highlights the importance of protecting intellectual property rights, including trademarks, and the need for businesses to conduct thorough searches and clearance before adopting a trade name or domain name.

2023/DHC/000868 
 
 
CS(COMM) 198/2022 
                                                               Page 1 of 11 
 
* 
IN  THE  HIGH  COURT  OF  DELHI  AT  NEW  DELHI 
% 
 
 
 
     Reserved on :   1st February, 2023  
            
 
 
 
    Decided on   :   7th  February, 2023 
+  
CS(COMM) 198/2022 & I.A. 4963/2022(O-XXXIX R-1 & 2 of CPC) 
 
 
AKTIEBOLAGET VOLVO & ORS.  
 
  ..... Plaintiffs 
Through: 
Mr. Pravin Anand with Ms. Vaishali 
Mittal 
and 
Mr. 
Karan 
Kamra, 
Advocates. 
 
 
 
 
versus 
 
 
VOLVO WHITE PAINTS INDUSTRIES & ORS.   ..... Defendants 
 
 
 
 
Through: 
None. 
 
CORAM: 
HON'BLE MR. JUSTICE AMIT BANSAL 
 
JUDGMENT 
 
I.A. 1921/2023 (O-XIII A R-2, 3 & 6 of CPC for Summary Judgment) & 
CS(COMM) 198/2022  
 
1. 
The present suit has been filed seeking relief of permanent injunction 
restraining the defendants from infringing the trademarks of the plaintiffs, 
passing off their goods as that of the plaintiffs‟ and other ancillary reliefs. 
PLEADINGS IN THE PLAINT 
2. 
The case set up by the plaintiffs in the plaint is as follows: 
2.1. Plaintiff no.1, AB Volvo, plaintiff no.2, Volvo Trademark Holding 
AB and plaintiff no.3, Volvo Car Corporation (hereinafter collectively 
referred to as „the plaintiffs‟), incorporated under the laws of Sweden, have 
their core business in transportation and automotive sector, including the 
business of manufacturing spare parts, accessories and ancillary parts for 
Digitally Signed By:AMIT
BANSAL
Signing Date:07.02.2023 17:07:54
Signature Not Verified

--- PAGE 2 ---
 
2023/DHC/000868 
 
 
CS(COMM) 198/2022 
                                                               Page 2 of 11 
 
vehicles under the trademark „VOLVO‟. 
2.2. Plaintiff no.1, incorporated on 5th May, 1915, executed a global deed 
of assignment in favour of plaintiff no.2, who became the subsequent 
proprietor of the plaintiffs‟ trademark „VOLVO‟ and subsequently licensed 
the use of the trademark „VOLVO‟ to plaintiffs no.1 and 3 in relation to 
their respective businesses.  
2.3. Plaintiff no.1 is an international automotive and transport vehicle 
group and employs approximately 1,15,000 persons worldwide. Plaintiff 
no.1 provides a wide spectrum of transportation related products and 
services, with superior quality and high standards of safety and 
environmental care to customers.  
2.4. The plaintiffs established an Indian flagship company, Volvo India 
Pvt. Ltd. in 1996 and launched their first „VOLVO‟ bus in India in 2001, 
followed by two car models in 2007. Plaintiffs sold almost 1361 cars in 
India in the year 2020. 
2.5. The plaintiffs are the registered proprietor of the trademark „VOLVO‟ 
and „VOLVO‟ formative marks in Classes 1, 2, 16, 37 and various other 
Classes of the Trade Marks Act, 1999. The earliest registration for the word 
mark „VOLVO‟ dates back to the year 1977. Details of the trademarks 
registrations of the plaintiffs‟ „VOLVO‟ marks in India have been tabulated 
at page no. 145 to 148 of the plaintiffs‟ documents filed with the plaint. The 
said marks of the plaintiffs are also registered by the plaintiffs in various 
foreign countries.  
2.6. The plaintiffs‟ „VOLVO‟ marks have acquired the status of „well-
Digitally Signed By:AMIT
BANSAL
Signing Date:07.02.2023 17:07:54
Signature Not Verified

--- PAGE 3 ---
 
2023/DHC/000868 
 
 
CS(COMM) 198/2022 
                                                               Page 3 of 11 
 
known trademarks‟ within the meaning of Section 2(1)(zg) of the Trade 
Marks Act, 1999, which fact is recognised in the judgment of Aktiebolaget 
Volvo of Sweden v. Volvo Steels Ltd. of Gujarat (India), (1998) 18 PTC 47. 
2.7. The plaintiffs are the registered domain name holders of the website, 
„www.volvobuses.com‟ and „www.volvobuses.in‟ catering to their segment 
of customers in India with the „.in‟ domain name. Additionally, the plaintiffs 
also hold the registration of the domain name „www.volvotrucks.in‟. 
2.8. Defendant no.1, Volvo White Paints Industries, is believed to be a 
partnership firm comprising the defendant no.2 and defendant no.3 
(hereinafter collectively referred to as „the defendants‟).  
2.9. In September, 2021, the plaintiffs got the knowledge that the 
defendants through the defendant no.1 were engaged in the business of 
manufacturing, dealing, selling/supplying products like wall putty, tile 
adhesive, LWC, Gypsum plaster etc., under the trade name „Volvo White 
Paints Industries‟. Pursuant thereto, the plaintiffs availed the services of an 
investigator in September - October 2021, to ascertain the business activities 
of the defendants as mentioned on their website.  
2.10. The investigation confirmed that the defendants are infringing the 
plaintiffs‟ registered and „well-known trademark‟ „VOLVO‟ as a part of 
their trade name „Volvo White Paints Industries‟ and in relation to their 
business activities. The defendants also operate the impugned domain name 
„www.volvowhite.com‟, 
which 
displays 
and 
use 
the 
mark, 
 as part of its trade name and uses the 
Digitally Signed By:AMIT
BANSAL
Signing Date:07.02.2023 17:07:54
Signature Not Verified

--- PAGE 4 ---
 
2023/DHC/000868 
 
 
CS(COMM) 198/2022 
                                                               Page 4 of 11 
 
plaintiffs‟   mark   in  the   meta-tags associated with the domain name, 
source code of the website hosted on the domain name. The defendants‟ 
email 
Ids 
„info@volvowhite.com‟, 
„sales@volvowhite.com‟ 
and 
„volvowhitepaints@gmail.com‟ also infringe the plaintiffs‟ mark. The 
packaging of the products of the defendant no.1 also bears the marks, 
VOLVO White Wall Putty, VOLVO White Tile adhesive, VOLVO White 
LWC, etc. which infringes the plaintiffs‟ registered and „well-known 
trademark‟ „VOLVO‟.  
2.11. The use of the mark „VOLVO‟ of the plaintiffs by the defendants in 
its trade name is intended to pass off the goods of the defendants as that of 
the plaintiffs‟. 
2.12. An application for registration of the trademark „VOLVO WHITE‟ 
(device) in Class 2 has been made by the defendants on a „proposed to be 
used basis‟, the status of which is reflected as „objected to‟ on the website of 
Indian Trademark Registry. 
2.13. Accordingly, the plaintiffs have filed the present suit. 
PROCEEDINGS IN THE SUIT 
3. 
This Court, vide order dated 31st March, 2022 granted an ex parte ad 
interim injunction in favour of the plaintiffs under I.A.4963/2022, 
restraining the defendants from using the mark „VOLVO‟. The relevant 
portion of the said order is as under: 
“25. Having heard learned counsel appearing on behalf of the 
Plaintiffs, this Court is of the view that Plaintiffs have made 
out a prima facie case for grant of ex parte ad-interim 
Digitally Signed By:AMIT
BANSAL
Signing Date:07.02.2023 17:07:54
Signature Not Verified

--- PAGE 5 ---
 
2023/DHC/000868 
 
 
CS(COMM) 198/2022 
                                                               Page 5 of 11 
 
injunction. Balance of convenience lies in favour of the 
Plaintiffs and they are likely to suffer irreparable harm in case 
the injunction, as prayed for, is not granted.  
26. Accordingly, Defendants, their subsidiaries, affiliates, 
franchisees, 
proprietors, 
officers, 
servants, 
agents, 
distributors, stockists, representatives and anyone acting for 
or on their behalf are hereby restrained from using the 
Plaintiffs’ name/trademark ‘VOLVO’ and/or any other 
name/trademark confusingly or deceptively similar there to, 
in relation to their business activities of manufacturing, 
selling and/or supplying, distribution and dealing in Wall 
Putty, Tile Adhesive, LWC, Gypsum Plaster, Exterior Cement 
Paint products etc or in relation to any other goods or 
services, in any manner, including but not limited to the 
trade name ‘VOLVO White Industries’; impugned domain 
name, www.volvowhite.com; in the meta-tags associated with 
the website; the source code of website hosted on the 
impugned domain name; as a part of the email ids 
info@volvowhite.com, 
sales@volvowhite.com 
and 
volvowhitepaints@gmail.com; third party listings, references 
in social media and/or any representation made by the 
Defendants, their affiliates, subsidiaries and on their behalf, 
in terms of relief sought in paragraph 78 (i) of the present 
application.” 
4. 
Vide the aforesaid order, two Local Commissioners were also 
appointed by this Court to seize and inventorize the infringing goods bearing 
the mark „VOLVO‟. The Local Commissioners found a large stock of 
infringing goods at the premises of the defendants, which were inventorized 
by them and seized and handed over on supardari to the defendants. The 
reports of the Local Commissioners have been placed on record. 
5. 
Office report notes that the defendants no.1, 2 and 3 were served 
through e-mail and WhatsApp. An affidavit of service has been filed on 
Digitally Signed By:AMIT
BANSAL
Signing Date:07.02.2023 17:07:54
Signature Not Verified

--- PAGE 6 ---
 
2023/DHC/000868 
 
 
CS(COMM) 198/2022 
                                                               Page 6 of 11 
 
behalf of the plaintiffs. As per the affidavit of service filed on behalf of the 
plaintiffs, the defendants were served through speed post, courier and e-
mail. The original speed post, courier receipts, tracking report and proof of 
service via e-mail have been filed along with the said affidavit. 
Consequently, the defendants were proceeded against ex parte on 28th July, 
2022. 
6. 
In view of the above, the counsel for the plaintiffs has filed the 
present application under Order XIII A Rules 2, 3 and 6 of the CPC for 
passing of a summary judgment.  
7. 
Counsel for the plaintiffs places reliance on the judgment of this 
Court in EBAY Inc. v. Mohd. Waseem, 2022 SCC OnLine Del 3879 to 
contend that in the event the defendants have failed to appear in the 
proceedings and voluntarily chosen not to respond to the plaint, it is 
indicative of the fact that the defendants have nothing substantial to urge, by 
way of a response to the allegations in the plaint. Counsel for the plaintiffs 
submits that this is a fit case where a Summary Judgment in terms of Order 
XIII-A of the Code of Civil Procedure, as applicable to commercial disputes 
of a specified value, read with Rule 27 of the Delhi High Court Intellectual 
Property Rights Division Rules, 2022 (in short, „IPD Rules‟), deserves to be 
passed in favour of the plaintiffs and against the defendants.  
ANALYSIS AND FINDINGS 
8. 
I have heard the counsel for the plaintiffs and perused the record of 
the case. 
Digitally Signed By:AMIT
BANSAL
Signing Date:07.02.2023 17:07:54
Signature Not Verified

--- PAGE 7 ---
 
2023/DHC/000868 
 
 
CS(COMM) 198/2022 
                                                               Page 7 of 11 
 
9. 
From the averments made in the plaint and the documents filed 
therewith, the plaintiffs have been able to prove that they are the registered 
proprietors of the mark „VOLVO‟. The plaintiffs have also been able to 
show their goodwill and reputation in respect of the mark „VOLVO‟ not 
only internationally but in India as well. The mark has acquired the status of 
a „well-known trademark‟ in terms of section 2(zg) of the Trade Marks Act, 
1999. The defendants have used the word mark „VOLVO‟ in its trade name, 
which is identical to the plaintiffs‟ name, to ride on the goodwill and 
reputation of the mark of the plaintiffs. The acts of the defendants amount to 
infringement of the mark of the plaintiffs and passing off the goods of the 
defendants as that of the plaintiffs. The defendants have not only taken 
unfair advantage of the reputation and goodwill of the plaintiffs‟ mark but 
also deceive unwary consumers of their association with the plaintiffs. Such 
acts of the defendants would also lead to dilution of the plaintiffs‟ mark. 
10. 
The domain name of the defendants is also deceptively similar to that 
of the plaintiffs and is likely to deceive the public of its association with the 
plaintiffs. In Anugya Gupta v. Ajay Kumar and Anr., 2022 SCC OnLine 
Del 1922, this Court applying the principles of the trade mark law has held 
that the right of a proprietor in a domain name is entitled to equal protection. 
The user traffic may be diverted due to the use of the same or similar 
domain name, which could result in a user mistakenly accessing one domain 
name instead of the one intended. A domain name may therefore, have all 
the characteristics of a trademark and could result in an act of passing off. 
Similarly, the use of „Volvo White Paints Industries‟ as a part of their trade 
Digitally Signed By:AMIT
BANSAL
Signing Date:07.02.2023 17:07:54
Signature Not Verified

--- PAGE 8 ---
 
2023/DHC/000868 
 
 
CS(COMM) 198/2022 
                                                               Page 8 of 11 
 
name/corporate name is also likely to deceive unwary consumers of their 
association with the plaintiffs. 
11. 
At this stage, it may be relevant to note that the defendants have been 
served through speed post, courier and e-mail. Moreover, the fact that local 
commissions were executed at the premises of the defendants would show 
that the defendants are aware of the pendency of the present suits. Despite 
the above, the defendants have failed to enter appearance in the suit and 
hence, were proceeded against ex parte on 28th July 2022.  
12. 
Plaintiffs have established statutory as well as common law rights on 
account of the long usage of the „VOLVO‟ marks. The plaintiffs would be 
gravely prejudiced if the defendants are permitted to use the impugned trade 
name and marks. Since the defendants have failed to enter appearance or 
even take any steps requisite to contest the present suit, despite having 
suffered an ad interim injunction order, it is evident that they have no 
defence to put forth on merits. The plaint is duly supported by the affidavit 
of the plaintiffs. I am of the opinion that no purpose would be served by 
directing the plaintiffs to lead ex parte evidence by filing an affidavit of 
examination in chief. Therefore, in my opinion, this is a fit case where a 
Summary Judgment in terms of Order XIII-A of the CPC, as applicable to 
commercial disputes of a specified value, read with Rule 27 of the IPD 
Rules, deserves to be passed in favour of the plaintiffs and against the 
defendants. Reference in this regard may be made to the judgment in Su-
Kam Power Systems Ltd. v. Kunwer Sachdev, 2019 SCC OnLine Del 
10764, has observed as under: 
Digitally Signed By:AMIT
BANSAL
Signing Date:07.02.2023 17:07:54
Signature Not Verified

--- PAGE 9 ---
 
2023/DHC/000868 
 
 
CS(COMM) 198/2022 
                                                               Page 9 of 11 
 
“90. To reiterate, the intent behind incorporating the summary 
judgment procedure in the Commercial Court Act, 2015 is to 
ensure disposal of commercial disputes in a time-bound 
manner. In fact, the applicability of Order XIIIA, CPC to 
commercial disputes, demonstrates that the trial is no longer 
the default procedure/norm. 
91. Rule 3 of Order XIIIA, CPC, as applicable to commercial 
disputes, empowers the Court to grant a summary judgement 
against the defendant where the Court considers that the 
defendant has no real prospects of successfully defending the 
claim and there is no other compelling reason why the claim 
should not be disposed of before recording of oral evidence. 
The expression “real” directs the Court to examine whether 
there is a “realistic” as opposed to “fanciful” prospects of 
success. This Court is of the view that the expression “no 
genuine issue requiring a trial” in Ontario Rules of Civil 
Procedure and “no other compelling reason…..for trial” in 
Commercial Courts Act can be read mutatis mutandis. 
Consequently, Order XIIIA, CPC would be attracted if the 
Court, while hearing such an application, can make the 
necessary finding of fact, apply the law to the facts and the 
same is a proportionate, more expeditious and less expensive 
means of achieving a fair and just result. 
92. Accordingly, unlike ordinary suits, Courts need not hold 
trial in commercial suits, even if there are disputed questions 
of fact as held by the Canadian Supreme Court in Robert 
Hryniak (supra), in the event, the Court comes to the 
conclusion that the defendant lacks a real prospect of 
successfully defending the claim.” 
13. 
The aforesaid principles are fully applicable in the facts and 
circumstances of the present case and therefore, the plaintiffs are entitled to 
a summary judgment.  
14. 
In view of the above, the present application is allowed. 
Digitally Signed By:AMIT
BANSAL
Signing Date:07.02.2023 17:07:54
Signature Not Verified

--- PAGE 10 ---
 
2023/DHC/000868 
 
 
CS(COMM) 198/2022 
                                                               Page 10 of 11 
 
RELIEF 
15. 
The various registrations and the long usage of the mark „VOLVO‟ by 
the plaintiffs, as also the goodwill vesting in the mark „VOLVO‟, entitles the 
plaintiffs for grant of permanent injunction and decree in terms of the plaint.  
16. 
Accordingly, the present suit is decreed in terms of prayer clauses „i‟, 
„ii‟, „iii‟ and „iv‟ of the plaint. 
17. 
Since the defendants have not appeared and rendered any accounts of 
profits, the said relief as sought in prayer clauses „vii‟ cannot be granted. 
Insofar as delivery up for the purpose of destruction, as sought in prayer 
clause „v‟ is concerned, the representatives of the plaintiffs are permitted to 
visit the premises of the defendants, where the inventory is lying and take 
seizure of the infringing products for the purpose of destruction.  
18. 
Insofar as the relief of damages as sought in prayer clause „vi‟ is 
concerned, reference may be made to the judgment in Hindustan Lever Ltd. 
v. Satish Kumar, 2012 SCC OnLine Del 1378. The relevant observations 
are set out below: 
“23. One of the reasons for granting relief of punitive damages 
is that despite of service of summons/notice, the defendant had 
chosen not to appear before the court. It shows that the 
defendant is aware of the illegal activities otherwise, he ought 
to have attended the proceedings and give justification for the 
said illegal acts. Since, the defendant has maintained silence, 
therefore, the guilt of the defendant speaks for itself and the 
court, under these circumstances, feels that in order to avoid 
future infringement, relief of punitive damages is to be granted 
in favour of the plaintiff.” 
19. 
In the present case, the defendants have blatantly infringed the 
Digitally Signed By:AMIT
BANSAL
Signing Date:07.02.2023 17:07:54
Signature Not Verified

--- PAGE 11 ---
 
2023/DHC/000868 
 
 
CS(COMM) 198/2022 
                                                               Page 11 of 11 
 
trademark of the plaintiffs and have also failed to appear before this Court. 
Applying the above principles and considering the large quantum of 
products that have been seized by the Local Commissioners, the plaintiffs 
are entitled to damages of Rs.5,00,000. 
20. 
As regard, the prayer clause „viii‟, counsel for the plaintiffs has filed a 
statement of costs. The statement of costs shows that Rs.4,51,500/- has 
already been incurred for court fees and the fees of the Local 
Commissioners. In addition, it is claimed that expenses to the tune of Rs. 
1,33,599/- have been incurred and Rs.4,53,707/- is the legal fees. This Court 
is convinced that this is a fit case for award of actual costs to the plaintiffs.  
Accordingly, Rs.10,00,000/- is awarded to the plaintiffs as costs to be paid 
by the defendants.  
21. 
Let the decree sheet be drawn up.  
22. 
All applications are disposed of in the above terms.  
 
 
AMIT BANSAL, J. 
FEBRUARY 07, 2023 
at 
Digitally Signed By:AMIT
BANSAL
Signing Date:07.02.2023 17:07:54
Signature Not Verified

tree_structure.title: Case Header and Parties
tree_structure.summary:
According to the PDF document "AKTIEBOLAGET VOLVO & ORS.VS. VOVLO WHITE PAINTS INDUSTRIES & ORS.pdf", the case header and parties are as follows:

The High Court of Delhi at New Delhi heard the case CS(COMM) 198/2022, reserved on February 1, 2023, and decided on February 7, 2023. The plaintiffs, Aktiebolaget Volvo and others, were represented by Mr. Pravin Anand, Ms. Vaishali Mittal, and Mr. Karan Kamra, advocates. The defendants, Volvo White Paints Industries and others, had no representation.

The plaintiffs sought relief of permanent injunction restraining the defendants from infringing their trademarks, passing off their goods, and other ancillary reliefs. The plaintiffs claimed to be the registered proprietors of the trademark "VOLVO" and "VOLVO" formative marks in various classes of the Trade Marks Act, 1999, with the earliest registration dating back to 1977.

The plaintiffs, incorporated under Swedish laws, have their core business in the transportation and automotive sector, manufacturing spare parts, accessories, and ancillary parts for vehicles under the trademark "VOLVO". The plaintiffs established an Indian flagship company in 1996 and launched their first "VOLVO" bus in India in 2001, followed by two car models in 2007, selling almost 1361 cars in India in 2020.

The court's judgment was digitally signed by Hon'ble Mr. Justice Amit Bansal on February 7, 2023. (Source: PDF document "AKTIEBOLAGET VOLVO & ORS.VS. VOVLO WHITE PAINTS INDUSTRIES & ORS.pdf")

The plaintiffs, Aktiebolaget Volvo and others, sought relief of permanent injunction against the defendants, Volvo White Paints Industries and others, for trademark infringement and passing off. The plaintiffs, incorporated under Swedish law, are in the transportation and automotive sector. The case was reserved on February 1, 2023, and the judgment was digitally signed by Amit Bansal on February 7, 2023. The plaintiffs were represented by Mr. Pravin Anand and others, while the defendants had no representation. (Source: 23. AKTIEBOLAGET VOLVO & ORS.VS. VOVLO WHITE PAINTS INDUSTRIES & ORS.pdf, page 1)

2023/DHC/000868

vehicles under the trademark „VOLVO‟.

2.4. The plaintiffs established an Indian flagship company, Volvo India 
Pvt. Ltd. in 1996 and launched their first „VOLVO‟ bus in India in 2001, 
followed by two car models in 2007. Plaintiffs sold almost 1361 cars in 
India in the year 2020. 
2.5. The plaintiffs are the registered proprietor of the trademark „VOLVO‟

Classes of the Trade Marks Act, 1999. The earliest registration for the word

registrations of the plaintiffs‟ „VOLVO‟ marks in India have been tabulated 
at page no. 145 to 148 of the plaintiffs‟ documents filed with the plaint. The 
said marks of the plaintiffs are also registered by the plaintiffs in various 
foreign countries.

tree_structure.title: Background and Facts
tree_structure.summary:
According to the PDF document "AKTIEBOLAGET VOLVO & ORS.VS. VOVLO WHITE PAINTS INDUSTRIES & ORS.pdf", the High Court of Delhi at New Delhi heard a case (CS(COMM) 198/2022) between Aktiebolaget Volvo and others (plaintiffs) and Volvo White Paints Industries and others (defendants). The plaintiffs alleged that the defendants infringed their well-known trademark "VOLVO" by using it as part of their trade name and in relation to their business activities.

The court granted an ex parte ad interim injunction in favor of the plaintiffs on March 31, 2022, restraining the defendants from using the mark "VOLVO". The plaintiffs claimed that the defendants' use of the mark was intended to pass off their goods as those of the plaintiffs. The defendants had also applied for registration of the trademark "VOLVO WHITE" in Class 2, which was objected to by the Indian Trademark Registry.

The plaintiffs argued that they had made out a prima facie case for the grant of an ex parte ad interim injunction, and that the balance of convenience lay in their favor. The court agreed, stating that the plaintiffs would likely suffer irreparable harm if the injunction was not granted. The case was reserved on February 1, 2023, and decided on February 7, 2023. The PDF document provides further details on the case, including the proceedings, arguments, and decisions made by the court. (Source: AKTIEBOLAGET VOLVO & ORS.VS. VOVLO WHITE PAINTS INDUSTRIES & ORS.pdf)
tree_structure.pdf_source: 23. AKTIEBOLAGET VOLVO & ORS.VS. VOVLO WHITE PAINTS INDUSTRIES & ORS.pdf

nodes.title: Page 3
nodes.summary: According to page 3 of the PDF "23. AKTIEBOLAGET VOLVO & ORS.VS. VOVLO WHITE PAINTS INDUSTRIES & ORS.pdf", the plaintiffs, Aktiebolaget Volvo, are the registered holders of well-known trademarks under Section 2(1)(zg) of the Trade Marks Act, 1999. They own domain names such as "www.volvobuses.com" and "www.volvobuses.in". The defendants, Volvo White Paints Industries, are allegedly infringing on the plaintiffs' trademark "VOLVO" as part of their trade name and operate the domain name "www.volvowhite.com". The investigation revealed that the defendants are manufacturing and selling products under the "Volvo White Paints Industries" name, violating the plaintiffs' trademark rights. The case, CS(COMM) 198/2022, was decided on February 7, 2023, in the High Court of Delhi. (Source: PDF page 3)

According to page 4 of the PDF "23. AKTIEBOLAGET VOLVO & ORS.VS. VOVLO WHITE PAINTS INDUSTRIES & ORS.pdf", the plaintiffs, Aktiebolaget Volvo & Ors., allege that the defendants' use of the mark "VOLVO" in their trade name, meta-tags, and packaging infringes on the plaintiffs' registered and well-known trademark "VOLVO". The defendants had also applied for registration of the trademark "VOLVO WHITE" in Class 2, which was objected to by the Indian Trademark Registry.

The court granted an ex parte ad interim injunction in favor of the plaintiffs on March 31, 2022, restraining the defendants from using the mark "VOLVO". The case, CS(COMM) 198/2022, was reserved on February 1, 2023, and decided on February 7, 2023. The plaintiffs were represented by Mr. Pravin Anand and Ms. Vaishali Mittal, among others. (Source: 23. tree_structure.title: Legal Arguments
tree_structure.summary:
According to the PDF document "AKTIEBOLAGET VOLVO & ORS.VS. VOVLO WHITE PAINTS INDUSTRIES & ORS.pdf", the legal proceedings involve a trademark infringement and passing off case. The plaintiffs, Aktiebolaget Volvo & Ors., filed a complaint against Vovlo White Paints Industries & Ors. in the High Court of Delhi at New Delhi (CS(COMM) 198/2022). The court reserved its judgment on February 1, 2023, and decided on February 7, 2023.

The plaintiffs' counsel, Mr. Pravin Anand, argued that the defendants had failed to respond to the plaint and had chosen not to appear in the proceedings, indicating that they had no substantial defense. The counsel relied on the judgment in EBAY Inc. v. Mohd. Waseem (2022 SCC OnLine Del 3879) to contend that a summary judgment should be passed in favor of the plaintiffs.

The court analyzed the case and found that the plaintiffs had proven their ownership of the "VOLVO" trademark and its goodwill and reputation in India and internationally. The defendants' use of the "VOLVO" mark in their trade name was deemed an infringement and passing off of the plaintiffs' goods. The court also found that the defendants' domain name was deceptively similar to the plaintiffs' domain name, which could lead to user confusion and diversion of traffic.

The court decided in favor of the plaintiffs, granting a summary judgment against the defendants. The details of the judgment, including any monetary awards or injunctions, are not specified in the provided section of the PDF document. (Source: AKTIEBOLAGET VOLVO & ORS.VS. VOVLO WHITE PAINTS INDUSTRIES & ORS.pdf, pages 6-8)
tree_structure.pdf_source: 23. AKTIEBOLAGET VOLVO & ORS.VS. VOVLO WHITE PAINTS INDUSTRIES & ORS.pdf

nodes.title: Page 6
nodes.summary: According to page 6 of the PDF "23. AKTIEBOLAGET VOLVO & ORS.VS. VOVLO WHITE PAINTS INDUSTRIES & ORS.pdf", the defendants were served through speed post, courier, and email, but failed to respond. Consequently, they were proceeded against ex parte on July 28, 2022. The counsel for the plaintiffs, Mr. Pravin Anand, filed an application for a summary judgment under Order XIII A Rules 2, 3, and 6 of the CPC. The counsel relied on the judgment in EBAY Inc. v. Mohd. Waseem (2022 SCC OnLine Del 3879) to argue that the defendants' failure to respond indicates they have nothing substantial to urge against the allegations. The court heard the counsel for the plaintiffs and perused the record on February 1, 2023, and decided on February 7, 2023. (Source: 2023/DHC/000868, CS(COMM) 198/2022)
nodes.content:
2023/DHC/000868 
 
 
CS(COMM) 198/2022 
                                                               Page 6 of 11 
 
behalf of the plaintiffs. As per the affidavit of service filed on behalf of the 
plaintiffs, the defendants were served through speed post, courier and e-
mail. The original speed post, courier receipts, tracking report and proof of 
service via e-mail have been filed along with the said affidavit. 
Consequently, the defendants were proceeded against ex parte on 28th July, 
2022. 
6. 
In view of the above, the counsel for the plaintiffs has filed the 
present application under Order XIII A Rules 2, 3 and 6 of the CPC for 
passing of a summary judgment.  
7. 
Counsel for the plaintiffs places reliance on the judgment of this 
Court in EBAY Inc. v. Mohd. Waseem, 2022 SCC OnLine Del 3879 to 
contend that in the event the defendants have failed to appear in the 
proceedings and voluntarily chosen not to respond to the plaint, it is 
indicative of the fact that the defendants have nothing substantial to urge, by 
way of a response to the allegations in the plaint. Counsel for the plaintiffs 
submits that this is a fit case where a Summary Judgment in terms of Order 
XIII-A of the Code of Civil Procedure, as applicable to commercial disputes 
of a specified value, read with Rule 27 of the Delhi High Court Intellectual 
Property Rights Division Rules, 2022 (in short, „IPD Rules‟), deserves to be 
passed in favour of the plaintiffs and against the defendants.  
ANALYSIS AND FINDINGS 
8. 
I have heard the counsel for the plaintiffs and perused the record of 
the case. 
Digitally Signed By:AMIT
BANSAL
Signing Date:07.02.2023 17:07:54
Signature Not Verified

nodes.title: Page 7
nodes.summary: According to page 7 of the PDF "AKTIEBOLAGET VOLVO & ORS.VS. VOVLO WHITE PAINTS INDUSTRIES & ORS.pdf", the plaintiffs, Aktiebolaget Volvo & Ors., have proven to be the registered proprietors of the mark "VOLVO" with goodwill and reputation internationally and in India. The defendants' use of the word mark "VOLVO" in their trade name is considered infringement and passing off. The court also finds the defendants' domain name to be deceptively similar to the plaintiffs', which could lead to user confusion and diversion of traffic. The case, CS(COMM) 198/2022, was decided on February 7, 2023, by the High Court of Delhi. The plaintiffs were represented by Mr. Pravin Anand and Ms. Vaishali Mittal, among others. The court applied principles of trade mark law, citing a previous case, Anugya Gupta v. Ajay Kumar and Anr. (Source: 2023/DHC/000868, PDF page 7)
nodes.content:
2023/DHC/000868 
 
 
CS(COMM) 198/2022 
                                                               Page 7 of 11 
 
9. 
From the averments made in the plaint and the documents filed 
therewith, the plaintiffs have been able to prove that they are the registered 
proprietors of the mark „VOLVO‟. The plaintiffs have also been able to 
show their goodwill and reputation in respect of the mark „VOLVO‟ not 
only internationally but in India as well. The mark has acquired the status of 
a „well-known trademark‟ in terms of section 2(zg) of the Trade Marks Act, 
1999. The defendants have used the word mark „VOLVO‟ in its trade name, 
which is identical to the plaintiffs‟ name, to ride on the goodwill and 
reputation of the mark of the plaintiffs. The acts of the defendants amount to 
infringement of the mark of the plaintiffs and passing off the goods of the 
defendants as that of the plaintiffs. The defendants have not only taken 
unfair advantage of the reputation and goodwill of the plaintiffs‟ mark but 
also deceive unwary consumers of their association with the plaintiffs. Such 
acts of the defendants would also lead to dilution of the plaintiffs‟ mark. 
10. 
The domain name of the defendants is also deceptively similar to that 
of the plaintiffs and is likely to deceive the public of its association with the 
plaintiffs. In Anugya Gupta v. Ajay Kumar and Anr., 2022 SCC OnLine 
Del 1922, this Court applying the principles of the trade mark law has held 
that the right of a proprietor in a domain name is entitled to equal protection. 
The user traffic may be diverted due to the use of the same or similar 
domain name, which could result in a user mistakenly accessing one domain 
name instead of the one intended. A domain name may therefore, have all 
the characteristics of a trademark and could result in an act of passing off. 
Similarly, the use of „Volvo White Paints Industries‟ as a part of their trade 
Digitally Signed By:AMIT
BANSAL
Signing Date:07.02.2023 17:07:54
Signature Not Verified
nodes.pdf_source: 23. AKTIEBOLAGET VOLVO & ORS.VS. VOVLO WHITE PAINTS INDUSTRIES & ORS.pdf

nodes.title: Page 8
nodes.summary: According to page 8 of the PDF "23. AKTIEBOLAGET VOLVO & ORS.VS. VOVLO WHITE PAINTS INDUSTRIES & ORS.pdf", the plaintiffs (Aktiebolaget Volvo & Ors.) have established statutory and common law rights to the "VOLVO" marks due to long usage. The defendants (Vovlo White Paints Industries & Ors.) failed to enter appearance despite being served and aware of the suit's pendency. The court decided to pass a Summary Judgment in favor of the plaintiffs, as the defendants had no defense to put forth on merits. The judgment was passed on February 7, 2023, with reference to the Su-Kam Power Systems Ltd. v. Kunwer Sachdev case (2019 SCC OnLine Del 10764). The plaintiffs were represented by Mr. Pravin Anand, Ms. Vaishali Mittal, and Mr. Karan Kamra, advocates.
nodes.content:
2023/DHC/000868 
 
 
CS(COMM) 198/2022 
                                                               Page 8 of 11 
 
name/corporate name is also likely to deceive unwary consumers of their 
association with the plaintiffs. 
11. 
At this stage, it may be relevant to note that the defendants have been 
served through speed post, courier and e-mail. Moreover, the fact that local 
commissions were executed at the premises of the defendants would show 
that the defendants are aware of the pendency of the present suits. Despite 
the above, the defendants have failed to enter appearance in the suit and 
hence, were proceeded against ex parte on 28th July 2022.  
12. 
Plaintiffs have established statutory as well as common law rights on 
account of the long usage of the „VOLVO‟ marks. The plaintiffs would be 
gravely prejudiced if the defendants are permitted to use the impugned trade 
name and marks. Since the defendants have failed to enter appearance or 
even take any steps requisite to contest the present suit, despite having 
suffered an ad interim injunction order, it is evident that they have no 
defence to put forth on merits. The plaint is duly supported by the affidavit 
of the plaintiffs. I am of the opinion that no purpose would be served by 
directing the plaintiffs to lead ex parte evidence by filing an affidavit of 
examination in chief. Therefore, in my opinion, this is a fit case where a 
Summary Judgment in terms of Order XIII-A of the CPC, as applicable to 
commercial disputes of a specified value, read with Rule 27 of the IPD 
Rules, deserves to be passed in favour of the plaintiffs and against the 
defendants. Reference in this regard may be made to the judgment in Su-
Kam Power Systems Ltd. v. Kunwer Sachdev, 2019 SCC OnLine Del 
10764, has observed as under: 
Digitally Signed By:AMIT
BANSAL
Signing Date:07.02.2023 17:07:54
Signature Not Verified
nodes.pdf_source: 23. AKTIEBOLAGET VOLVO & ORS.VS. VOVLO WHITE PAINTS INDUSTRIES & ORS.pdf

nodes.title: Page 9
nodes.summary: According to page 9 of the PDF "AKTIEBOLAGET VOLVO & ORS.VS. VOVLO WHITE PAINTS INDUSTRIES & ORS.pdf" (2023/DHC/000868, CS(COMM) 198/2022), the High Court of Delhi discusses the summary judgment procedure in commercial disputes. The court cites Rule 3 of Order XIIIA, CPC, which allows for summary judgment if the defendant has no real prospects of successfully defending the claim. The court applies this principle to the present case, finding that the plaintiffs are entitled to a summary judgment. The application is allowed, as decided on February 7, 2023, by Judge Amit Bansal. The court's decision is based on the Commercial Court Act, 2015, which aims to dispose of commercial disputes in a time-bound manner. (Source: PDF page 9)
nodes.content:
2023/DHC/000868 
 
 
CS(COMM) 198/2022 
                                                               Page 9 of 11 
 
“90. To reiterate, the intent behind incorporating the summary 
judgment procedure in the Commercial Court Act, 2015 is to 
ensure disposal of commercial disputes in a time-bound 
manner. In fact, the applicability of Order XIIIA, CPC to 
commercial disputes, demonstrates that the trial is no longer 
the default procedure/norm. 
91. Rule 3 of Order XIIIA, CPC, as applicable to commercial 
disputes, empowers the Court to grant a summary judgement 
against the defendant where the Court considers that the 
defendant has no real prospects of successfully defending the 
claim and there is no other compelling reason why the claim 
should not be disposed of before recording of oral evidence. 
The expression “real” directs the Court to examine whether 
there is a “realistic” as opposed to “fanciful” prospects of 
success. This Court is of the view that the expression “no 
genuine issue requiring a trial” in Ontario Rules of Civil 
Procedure and “no other compelling reason…..for trial” in 
Commercial Courts Act can be read mutatis mutandis. 
Consequently, Order XIIIA, CPC would be attracted if the 
Court, while hearing such an application, can make the 
necessary finding of fact, apply the law to the facts and the 
same is a proportionate, more expeditious and less expensive 
means of achieving a fair and just result. 
92. Accordingly, unlike ordinary suits, Courts need not hold 
trial in commercial suits, even if there are disputed questions 
of fact as held by the Canadian Supreme Court in Robert 
Hryniak (supra), in the event, the Court comes to the 
conclusion that the defendant lacks a real prospect of 
successfully defending the claim.” 
13. 
The aforesaid principles are fully applicable in the facts and 
circumstances of the present case and therefore, the plaintiffs are entitled to 
a summary judgment.  
14. 
In view of the above, the present application is allowed. 
Digitally Signed By:AMIT
BANSAL
Signing Date:07.02.2023 17:07:54
Signature Not Verified
nodes.pdf_source: 23. AKTIEBOLAGET VOLVO & ORS.VS. VOVLO WHITE PAINTS INDUSTRIES & ORS.pdf

tree_structure.title: Court Decision
tree_structure.summary:
According to the PDF document "AKTIEBOLAGET VOLVO & ORS.VS. VOVLO WHITE PAINTS INDUSTRIES & ORS.pdf", the High Court of Delhi at New Delhi decreed in favor of the plaintiffs, Aktiebolaget Volvo & Ors., in a trademark infringement case (CS(COMM) 198/2022). The court reserved its decision on February 1, 2023, and delivered its verdict on February 7, 2023.

The plaintiffs were represented by Mr. Pravin Anand, Ms. Vaishali Mittal, and Mr. Karan Kamra. The court granted permanent injunction and decree in terms of the plaint, entitling the plaintiffs to relief due to the defendants' blatant infringement of the "VOLVO" trademark and their failure to appear in court.

The court awarded damages of Rs.5,00,000 to the plaintiffs, applying the principle of punitive damages as stated in the judgment of Hindustan Lever Ltd. v. Satish Kumar (2012 SCC OnLine Del 1378). Additionally, the court awarded Rs.10,00,000 as costs to the plaintiffs, considering the expenses incurred for court fees, Local Commissioners' fees, and legal fees.

The defendants were ordered to deliver up the infringing products for destruction, and the plaintiffs' representatives were permitted to visit the defendants' premises to seize the inventory. The court disposed of all applications in the above terms, and the decree sheet was directed to be drawn up. The judgment was delivered by Amit Bansal, J., on February 7, 2023, as stated in the PDF document.
tree_structure.pdf_source: 23. AKTIEBOLAGET VOLVO & ORS.VS. VOVLO WHITE PAINTS INDUSTRIES & ORS.pdf

nodes.title: Page 10
nodes.summary: According to page 10 of the PDF "23. AKTIEBOLAGET VOLVO & ORS.VS. VOVLO WHITE PAINTS INDUSTRIES & ORS.pdf", the court has decreed the present suit in favor of the plaintiffs, Aktiebolaget Volvo & Ors., granting permanent injunction and decree in terms of prayer clauses "i", "ii", "iii", and "iv" of the plaint. The defendants, who did not appear in court, have been found to have blatantly infringed the plaintiffs' mark "VOLVO". The court has permitted the plaintiffs to seize and destroy infringing products. The court also considered granting punitive damages, citing the judgment in Hindustan Lever Ltd. v. Satish Kumar (2012 SCC OnLine Del 1378), but the amount is not specified. The decision was made on February 7, 2023, by the High Court of Delhi. (Source: 23. AKTIEBOLAGET VOLVO & ORS.VS. VOVLO WHITE PAINTS INDUSTRIES & ORS.pdf, page 10)
nodes.content:
2023/DHC/000868 
 
 
CS(COMM) 198/2022 
                                                               Page 10 of 11 
 
RELIEF 
15. 
The various registrations and the long usage of the mark „VOLVO‟ by 
the plaintiffs, as also the goodwill vesting in the mark „VOLVO‟, entitles the 
plaintiffs for grant of permanent injunction and decree in terms of the plaint.  
16. 
Accordingly, the present suit is decreed in terms of prayer clauses „i‟, 
„ii‟, „iii‟ and „iv‟ of the plaint. 
17. 
Since the defendants have not appeared and rendered any accounts of 
profits, the said relief as sought in prayer clauses „vii‟ cannot be granted. 
Insofar as delivery up for the purpose of destruction, as sought in prayer 
clause „v‟ is concerned, the representatives of the plaintiffs are permitted to 
visit the premises of the defendants, where the inventory is lying and take 
seizure of the infringing products for the purpose of destruction.  
18. 
Insofar as the relief of damages as sought in prayer clause „vi‟ is 
concerned, reference may be made to the judgment in Hindustan Lever Ltd. 
v. Satish Kumar, 2012 SCC OnLine Del 1378. The relevant observations 
are set out below: 
“23. One of the reasons for granting relief of punitive damages 
is that despite of service of summons/notice, the defendant had 
chosen not to appear before the court. It shows that the 
defendant is aware of the illegal activities otherwise, he ought 
to have attended the proceedings and give justification for the 
said illegal acts. Since, the defendant has maintained silence, 
therefore, the guilt of the defendant speaks for itself and the 
court, under these circumstances, feels that in order to avoid 
future infringement, relief of punitive damages is to be granted 
in favour of the plaintiff.” 
19. 
In the present case, the defendants have blatantly infringed the 
Digitally Signed By:AMIT
BANSAL

nodes.title: Page 11
nodes.summary: According to page 11 of the PDF "23. AKTIEBOLAGET VOLVO & ORS.VS. VOVLO WHITE PAINTS INDUSTRIES & ORS.pdf", the court ruled in favor of the plaintiffs, Aktiebolaget Volvo & Ors. The defendants were found to have infringed on the plaintiffs' trademark and failed to appear in court. The court awarded damages of Rs.5,00,000 to the plaintiffs. Additionally, the court awarded actual costs of Rs.10,00,000 to the plaintiffs, as claimed by their counsel, Mr. Pravin Anand. The case, CS(COMM) 198/2022, was decided on February 7, 2023, by Judge Amit Bansal. The decree sheet was ordered to be drawn up, and all applications were disposed of in the above terms. (Source: PDF "23. AKTIEBOLAGET VOLVO & ORS.VS. VOVLO WHITE PAINTS INDUSTRIES & ORS.pdf", page 11)
nodes.content:
2023/DHC/000868 
 
 
CS(COMM) 198/2022 
                                                               Page 11 of 11 
 
trademark of the plaintiffs and have also failed to appear before this Court. 
Applying the above principles and considering the large quantum of 
products that have been seized by the Local Commissioners, the plaintiffs 
are entitled to damages of Rs.5,00,000. 
20. 
As regard, the prayer clause „viii‟, counsel for the plaintiffs has filed a 
statement of costs. The statement of costs shows that Rs.4,51,500/- has 
already been incurred for court fees and the fees of the Local 
Commissioners. In addition, it is claimed that expenses to the tune of Rs. 
1,33,599/- have been incurred and Rs.4,53,707/- is the legal fees. This Court 
is convinced that this is a fit case for award of actual costs to the plaintiffs.  
Accordingly, Rs.10,00,000/- is awarded to the plaintiffs as costs to be paid 
by the defendants.  
21. 
Let the decree sheet be drawn up.  
22. 
All applications are disposed of in the above terms.  
 
 
AMIT BANSAL, J. 
FEBRUARY 07, 2023 
at 
Digitally Signed By:AMIT
BANSAL
